comment.body:
> [angristan](#comment_1_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7): We can't change without restarting ZeroNet ?

You only need to restart to enable the plugin.  To change identities, just log out from ZeroHello and log back in with your identity's private key

> [yeti](#comment_1_14tJBPnxcrF9kMK5v7DULWnaJx3JepirXb): I'm updating using "git pull"...Having used a symlink instead of renaming the plugin's directory I'm curiously waiting for an update of this plugin...;-)

That is interesting - Maybe they could switch to the way ubuntu does it...

> [yeti](#comment_2_14tJBPnxcrF9kMK5v7DULWnaJx3JepirXb): Using git is not distribution specific.

Nah, I just meant that ubuntu organizes their config files into folders with links to show enabled/disabled...

ie: 

/etc/nginx/sites-available/mycoolsite.conf can exist and be under git control, but
doesn't become enabled until /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/mycoolsite.conf exists.

The standard way is to create a link in enabled/ which points to available/

> [yeti](#comment_3_14tJBPnxcrF9kMK5v7DULWnaJx3JepirXb): What about multiuser and deleting sites?I get "This function is disabled on this proxy" now...

Yeah, I get that too :( Time to file a bug

Looks like that was intentional, because it isn't "multiuser safe"

https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/commit/36d3268cf7de35ea51d423f0f2767e903b5fb077

They have a point, if you imagine using this sort of setup in a proxy, but for myself I wish it'd remember who a site was cached for and allow that person to delete

> [zaphod](#comment_1_1JA2umSc9f7VSNLaYLs1Cpk7rpvS4p18xe): Seconded. Just enabled multiuser to test it out and will probably disable it again as soon as I want to delete pages, this is a major dealbreaker.Maybe make it a toggle somewhere, somehow?

I just removed those three lines and the functionality is back (after a restart)

Ah wow, that's totally what I was thinking :) That's cool - I only got as far as creating a FaceBook app.

I actually did suggest the system to a bunch of coworkers, but it got icky when it came time to write down who trusted whom :)

> [ks](#comment_1_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): That's a bit like the Ripple Network works: Ripple IOUs.

> [ks](#comment_2_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): There's also Stellar, created by some of the creators of Ripple. I'm not sure I like either — they're too centralized — but I like the idea.
> Within a smallish group there's a thing like https://grouptabs.5apps.com/ that eases tracking of expenses in a group, but I gather you're more keen on a bigger scale.

Nah, I was more interested in implementing it in small real life social groups.  A small team at work could issue and accept IOUs from one another for sharing a bar tab for example

> [pycole](#comment_3_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): Neat, I'll have to check that one out. Mind if I shamelessly pimp my own referral link?

Yeah, but that site gives out less than 1000 satoshi for a complicated Captcha and only once every 5 minutes... http://10000satoshi.com/register?ref=233527 is giving out 10,000 - 50,000 satoshi with a very simple Captcha and no wait between claims
